Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel funding for 2017 Logic Mentoring Workshop (LMW) at (LICS); Reykjavik, Iceland; June, 2017

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant will enable students to attend the Logic Mentoring Workshop (LMW 2017) which will be co-located with the International ACM/IEEE Symposium on Logic in Computer Science (LICS) to be held in Reykjavik (Iceland), June 2017. LICS is one of the premier conferences in computer science, dedicated to the advancement of the logic and semantics. The purpose of Logic Mentoring Workshop is to provide mentoring and career advice to early-stage graduate students, to attract them to pursue research careers in the area of computer-aided verification.

Attending a conference can be a transformative experience for young researchers. It exposes them to cutting-edge research and can help them make connections to other students and senior researchers in the area. The funded students will attend LICS, a top conference where they will learn about current research problems and interact with leaders in the field, and the LMW workshop which will focus on mentoring and career advice specific to early-stage graduate students who aim to pursue research careers in the area of computer-aided verification.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2nd Logic Mentoring Workshop (LMW) took place on June 18, 2017, as a satellite event of the ACM/IEEE Symposium on Logic in Computer Science (LICS) in Reykjavik, Iceland. LICS is the flagship conference in computational logic, and one of the premier conferences in all of theoretical computer science. It is therefore a critical meeting for students working in the area to attend. The purpose of the workshop was to help students and postdocs working in logic to achieve their goals, and to motivate them to pursue a research career, either in academia or in industry. In particular, we wanted to promote the representation of women and minorities in the community, and more generally in computer science. To this end, we were pleased that over a quarter of our 48 registered participants were women.

The workshop program comprised a number of talks from leaders and rising stars in the com- munity, as well as a panel session. The talks covered a variety of topics, from the influence of logic in the wider area, to practical subjects such as collaboration and research grants. The intention of these talks was to give the participants an insight into the role of logic research in academia and industry and what its practice constitutes over the course of a career. The panel session provided an opportunity, at the end of the workshop, for the participants to pose their own questions to a selection of researchers at various points in their career. Chaired by the organisers, who selected certain topics in advance, it was a vibrant and interactive discussion which exposed the students to issues surrounding logic research and academia, offering several differing viewpoints therein. The full programme is given below, and further details may be found at https://lics.siglog.org/lics17/lmw.html.

The workshop had 48 registered participants. A total of 21 students were offered (partial) ex- pense reimbursements for participating, thanks to sponsorship from NSF, Amazon and ACM/SIGLOG. Due to the positive reception, the workshop has been renewed for a third edition, which will take place as a satellite event of LICS in July 2018.
